docs.lead_paragraph: 'Veal chops, one for each of us,'' I said over the phone. ''The fatter osso buco kind, or the ones like a pork chop?'' Sherry asked.

docs.snippet: New Zealand has made Cheddar for a long time, which is no surprise, considering the country's English heritage. One of its largest producers, Kapiti, is now sending the cheese to American shops. It is deep ivory and aged four years, and it has a m...
docs.abstract: Photo of Kapiti cheddar-style cheese from New Zealand (Food Stuff column) (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: New Zealand has made Cheddar for a long time, which is no surprise, considering the country's English heritage. One of its largest producers, Kapiti, is now sending the cheese to American shops. It is deep ivory and aged four years, and it has a mild but richly complex flavor, with a firm, slightly crumbly texture. The cheese is not shipped in wheels, but in one-pound wedges coated in wax, above left. Another Kapiti cheese is a triple-cream blue, above right, a tangy, mouth-filling, gently flavored cow's milk cheese that comes in a fat cylinder. The Cheddar is $9.95 a wedge at Ideal Cheese. Barefoot Contessa in East Hampton, N.Y. and Market Basket in Franklin Lakes, N.J. sell it for $11.99 a pound. The blue is $12.95 a pound at Ideal Cheese, $15.99 at Market Basket and $12.99 at Barefoot Contessa.

headline.main: Aged Four Years in New Zealand, Then a Little Longer on the Trip

docs.snippet: Spicy brownies, fat cookies, chocolate clusters with either peanut butter or strawberry shortcake centers, dessert sauces, truffle lollipops, chocolate bars and assorted truffles fill the shelves at the bright new Chocolate Bar, 48 Eighth Avenue (...
docs.abstract: Chocolate Bar, shop that carries only work of New York bakers and chocolatiers, opens at 48 Eighth Avenue, at Jane Street; photos (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Spicy brownies, fat cookies, chocolate clusters with either peanut butter or strawberry shortcake centers, dessert sauces, truffle lollipops, chocolate bars and assorted truffles fill the shelves at the bright new Chocolate Bar, 48 Eighth Avenue (Jane Street). The owners, Alison Nelson and Matt Lewis, below, carry only the work of New York bakers and chocolatiers, including Jacques Torres, Garrison Confections, Sweet Bliss and Lunchbox. The shop also sells coffee (48 cents a cup this month), iced chocolate drinks and chocolate-flavored teas.

headline.main: For Those With the Craving, a Most Chocolaty Spot

docs.snippet: As a Christmas present last year, Timmie, Tad's sister, gave me six of her favorite recipes: among them, tabbouleh, corn chowder and her raspberry-almond vacherin. She must have read my mind, I thought. For months, with Tad's gentle encouragement,...
docs.abstract: Amanda Hesser article on compiling list of her favorite recipes; recipes; drawing; photo (M)/
docs.lead_paragraph: As a Christmas present last year, Timmie, Tad's sister, gave me six of her favorite recipes: among them, tabbouleh, corn chowder and her raspberry-almond vacherin. She must have read my mind, I thought. For months, with Tad's gentle encouragement, I had been trying to distill the mass of recipes in my head down to a manageable stable of favorites, a repertory that I could rely on and that friends and family, and Tad in particular, would look forward to. There were a few natural choices. A couple of years ago, my mother taught me to make her dense but moist chocolate birthday cake. She calls it ''dump-it cake'' because you mix all of the ingredients in a pot over medium heat, then dump the batter into a cake pan to bake. For the icing, you melt Nestlé's semisweet-chocolate chips and swirl them together with sour cream. It sounds as if it's straight from the Pillsbury Bake-Off, but it tastes as if it's straight from Payard. Everyone loves it.

docs.snippet: The refurbished Bemelmans Bar, in the Hotel Carlyle, has a savory twist on the madeleine. The bar, named for Ludwig Bemelmans, the creator of Madeline, the winsome French schoolgirl, serves warm cheese madeleines made by Jean-Louis Dumonet, the Ca...
docs.abstract: Comment on madeleines served at refurbished Bemelmans Bar in Hotel Carlyle; photos (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: The refurbished Bemelmans Bar, in the Hotel Carlyle, has a savory twist on the madeleine. The bar, named for Ludwig Bemelmans, the creator of Madeline, the winsome French schoolgirl, serves warm cheese madeleines made by Jean-Louis Dumonet, the Carlyle's chef. A dish of them is $6; this month they are free with drinks from 5:30 to 7:30 p.m.

headline.main: Madeleines for Madeline? Pint-Sized Bites for Happy Hour

docs.snippet: They look like golden navel oranges, but they are actually sweet Meyer lemons, about twice the usual size. The grower, Armand Bryl of Samsula, Fla., near Daytona Beach, said, ''I just use natural fish and seaweed fertilizer and then let the ladybu...
docs.abstract: Comment on sweet Meyer lemons, about twice usual size, grown at Samsula, Florida; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: They look like golden navel oranges, but they are actually sweet Meyer lemons, about twice the usual size. The grower, Armand Bryl of Samsula, Fla., near Daytona Beach, said, ''I just use natural fish and seaweed fertilizer and then let the ladybugs do their job.'' Only some of his lemons are giants, and those he sends to Grace's Marketplace, 1237 Third Avenue (71st Street), where they are $2.99 a pound. Each of the lemons (shown with a regular lemon, below) yields about a cup of juice. For granita, combine two cups Meyer lemon juice with seven tablespoons sugar dissolved in a cup of simmering water. Put in the freezer in a metal pan. Mix with a fork when slushy, and occasionally until frozen. Remove pulp from juiced lemons, and serve granita in the shells.

headline.main: Big and Sweet: Who'd Think It's a Lemon?

docs.snippet: Bierkraft, a new shop at 191 Fifth Avenue (Union Street) in Park Slope, Brooklyn, is not just a place to choose from among more than 350 kinds of beer. It's a place to learn about them as well. The owners, Daphne and Richard Scholz, have a tasting...
docs.abstract: Bierkraft, new shop in Park Slope, Brooklyn
docs.lead_paragraph: Bierkraft, a new shop at 191 Fifth Avenue (Union Street) in Park Slope, Brooklyn, is not just a place to choose from among more than 350 kinds of beer. It's a place to learn about them as well. The owners, Daphne and Richard Scholz, have a tasting room where experts give free classes. Garrett Oliver, the brewmaster of the Brooklyn Brewery in Williamsburg, gave one recently about holiday beers.

headline.main: Beer in Bottles and From Scratch

docs.snippet: This month, Estiatorio Milos, the Greek seafood restaurant at 125 West 55th Street, is offering free samples of kakavia, a stew that fishermen traditionally make on the beach, to customers at the start of dinner or while they wait for tables. The ...
docs.abstract: Estiatorio Milos, Greek seafood restaurant in Manhattan, is offering free samples of kakavia, stew that fishermen traditionally make on beach; recipe; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: This month, Estiatorio Milos, the Greek seafood restaurant at 125 West 55th Street, is offering free samples of kakavia, a stew that fishermen traditionally make on the beach, to customers at the start of dinner or while they wait for tables. The chef and owner, Costas Spiliadis, is at the ladle at left. As an elaborate two-course main dish, kakavia is $120 for two (more than 10 pounds of whole fish go into it).

headline.main: A Fisherman's Stew To Make at Home (Hold the Beach)

docs.snippet: Oreos with a glass of milk are a given. These new cookies are particularly good for nibbling with a good cup of coffee. Dark chocolate Latté sandwich cookies made by Uniquely Together Gourmet, a company in Skokie, Ill., have a creamy filling subt...
docs.abstract: Dark chocolate Latte sandwich cookies are made by Uniquely Together Gourmet in Skokie, Ill; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Oreos with a glass of milk are a given. These new cookies are particularly good for nibbling with a good cup of coffee. Dark chocolate Latté sandwich cookies made by Uniquely Together Gourmet, a company in Skokie, Ill., have a creamy filling subtly flavored with coffee. The company also makes a version covered with milk chocolate. A tin holding a little more than a pound of the plain cookies is $12; the chocolate-covered ones are $20, from (800) 613-7276. They are also sold at Bloomingdale's, Crate & Barrel and Nieman Marcus.

headline.main: Oreo Lookalikes With an Italian Accent

docs.snippet: These perky infant amaranth leaves are called microgreens even though they are a gorgeous burgundy. Grown organically in the Catskills, they add a bittersweet, almost wheaty flavor to a salad or can be used as a topping for soups, open-face sandwi...
docs.abstract: Perky infant amaranth leaves, microgreens, noted; photo (Food Stuff column) (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: These perky infant amaranth leaves are called microgreens even though they are a gorgeous burgundy. Grown organically in the Catskills, they add a bittersweet, almost wheaty flavor to a salad or can be used as a topping for soups, open-face sandwiches, eggs or even seafood dishes. One-ounce containers of De La Terre amaranth are $3.95 at Dean & DeLuca and Agata & Valentina through December.

headline.main: Greens of a Different Color, in Miniature
